<@U0NNZ694Z>: The only reason why I haven’t completely moved from maven is that i have to wait 3+ secs to run a build script

With Android Studio 2.0 and instant run my builds never take more than 3 seconds (but then again it’s not really re-compiling dependencies and stuff).  Maven is too primitive for me at this point.  Gradle is written with Groovy — a programming language.  I’m hooked.

im not complaining about the all the nice things you ‘can’ do with it like multi module multi variants.. its everything else about it that’s the problem. When using `getActivity()` in a Fragment in an async callback should I use `if (getActivity() == null)` or `if(isAdded())` ?
really neither because that means you have potentially leaked your activity
Keep a `WeakReference` I would think, although I’ve never handled anything like that.
I know between your two options, `isAdded()` should work though
Well simpler question, is there any difference between the two conditions above? One better than the other?
Yeah … it _should_ work gah, but I have a feeling `getActivity()` could be `null` even after that. That’s just be being paranoid though
That should be adequate
great thanks!
Guess a more general question, if I need a Context within an async callback, `getActivity()` was just the most convenient way to get a context in a `Fragment`. Is there a proper solution?

It works, but always always check it
Have you ever used `WeakReference`?
take a context as a parameter in the constructor and make it do `this.context = context.getApplicationContext()`
I think once but never really understood it
unless you need to inflate resources, use application context
<@U055GGAHS>: thanks
as <@U0NNZ694Z> notes, weakreference is an option but that is typically not necessary

There are a few more things besides inflation that an applicationContext can’t do btw, make sure you know exactly what you’re doing when you use applicationContext vs a normal Activity reference or something
<http://i.stack.imgur.com/1o5MI.png>

The best option is honestly to avoid asynctask as usually your own threading is generally easier via RX or other libs. The only good argument for asynctask that I know of is that when it comes time to use something like espresso, asynctask queues on the main looper and also uses a particular executor which lets testing know you have async operations it needs to wait on to complete. You can work around that though with IdlingResource implementations
Well showing a dialog is inflating resources

and application context ‘can’ do that but it doesn’t have the proper contextwrapper, past that it doesnt work because dialogs have coupling to activities so its not the context thats the problem, its the parent (but thats kinda indirectly the problem of the context)
great explanation

<https://sites.google.com/a/android.com/tools/recent/androidstudio20beta6availableinthecanarychannel|Android Studio 2.0 Beta 6 Available in the Canary Channel>
We've just pushed Android Studio 2.0 Beta 6 to the canary channel, as well as 2.0.0-beta6 of the Gradle plugin to jcenter. If all goes according to plan, we hope to roll this out to the beta channel in a few days. This build fixes a couple of important bugs related to instant run:Apps that were using multiple processes (via android:process in the manifest) were not being updated properly with Instant Run. For the time being, we have turned off Instant Run in such a scenario.Certain devices...
